text: I'm Christopher gray architectural
historian and streetscapes columnist for
The New York Times every block I walked
down i'm looking for an odd detail a
strange building new york's little
mysteries it's my job to solve them the
city and its architecture is my beat the
majestic banking floor of the 1920s is
practically disappeared but instead of
demolition and multiplexing the grand
banking halls of New York are almost all
still intact out in the commercial
hubbub of Brooklyn's atlantic center one
of these still survives in an unusual
new use let's go
welcome to the Williamsburg savings bank
at one time fourth largest in the United
States I remember banking in the old
days now what you do you go into this
low small room with fluorescent lights
and little pieces of litter all over the
floor and everybody lines up against the
wall it's kind of like going into a
public restroom but in my 20s I'd walk
into a big Cathedral space like this
mosaics murals tapestries precious
marbles stones inset and ironwork bronze
work it was like walking into a treasure
house of the gods
I don't know about you but my current
bank definitely doesn't have a fireplace
this magnificent room is full of the
iconography of American capitalism the
back of gold you want to accumulate by
the end of your life the key to your
riches the lamp of knowledge which
you'll use to accumulate the cornucopia
of your labor the bee hive of Industry
the nobility of Labor the message is
clear get a job save your money deposit
it here everything's going to be just
fine
no bank today needs this kind of
hardware two feet of Steel what banks
need today to keep your money safe is
not hardware you need software
there's the story going around that this
was the window for the bank president in
case of a robbery he'd come out with a
sniper rifle and take him out you know I
don't really believe that I think I
could still hit a squirrel with a 22
from this distance but from what I hear
the sound of gunfire really drives away
depositors this hasn't been a bank for
years now you can rent it out for events
and on the weekends it's a flea market
these giant financial monsters were too
big to fail that is the banks themselves
may have disappeared but they're great
halls of somehow escaped the wrecking
ball and there are about half a dozen
left in New York
the Williamsburg Savings Bank is long
gone now it's the Brooklyn Flea where
you can still get a great steel
